Minimum Wage Through the Years


The federal minimum wage first came to be in 1938 with the passing of the Fair Labor Standards Act. The law made it so people were compensated at least somewhat for their labor. Over the years this law has been amended time and time again to include jobs like retail, service, and construction workers, as well as "end" pay discrimination based on sex or age. Several amendments have also raised the minimum wage; however, the increase of the minimum wage has not always been guaranteed, and is not set in relation to cost of living or inflation. According to Stephanie Luce at City University of New York, the minimum wage "is completely dependent upon political negotiations, and its level depended upon which forces had power," which could be looked at to determine why the minimum wage has not had more consistent change.


Taking a look at the federal minimum wage we can see its long overdue for an increase.
